headline: Calamos unveils ‚ÄòProtected Bitcoin‚Äô strategy for institutional investors
summary: Investment firm Calamos has unveiled a new investment strategy aimed at limiting Bitcoin‚Äôs downside potential. Bitcoin (BTC) is becoming increasingly attractive to institutions, but many still view it as too risky. In response, on June 7, global investment firm Calamos introduced its ‚Äúprotected Bitcoin‚Äù strategy , designed to limit both the downside and the upside of Bitcoin exposure. The firm noted that although Bitcoin has reached a $2 trillion valuation, institutional investors remain concerned about its volatility. As a result, most allocate just 1‚Äì2% of their portfolios to BTC to avoid outsized risk exposure. Calamos has structured its strategy to offer some upside participation while managing risk by combining Bitcoin futures with U.S. Treasuries. Specifically, the firm purchases zero-coupon U.S. Treasury bonds maturing at the end of the year. You might also like: Over a third of Bitcoin‚Äôs circulating supply is in instituitional hands: report Calamos pairs treasuries with Bitcoin These Treasuries act as a protective floor in predefined worst-case scenarios, limiting losses to 0%, 10%, or 20%, depending on the risk tier. Simultaneously, Calamos buys call options on the Bitcoin Index to capture potential gains. To fund these, the firm also sells out-of-the-money call options, effectively capping the upside between 25% and 60%. Calamos risk-reward tiers | Source: Calamos Each risk-return tier is benchmarked to familiar asset classes. The 100% protected Bitcoin tier mirrors the risk profile of Treasuries, offering capital preservation with virtually no downside risk. The second tier is comparable to gold or alternative assets, while the third tier aligns with equities in terms of expected returns and volatility. Calamos believes this structured approach could enhance Bitcoin‚Äôs appeal relative to traditional assets. However, timing remains critical. Traders must hold positions to maturity to benefit from the downside protection; early exits could result in loss of principal. While rare, another risk includes potential sovereign debt default, which the firm notes is highly unlikely. Read more: Bitcoin nears 31% of portfolios as institutions rotate out of Solana: Bybit

headline: Jack Dorsey releases details of his p2p messaging app Bitchat
summary: The co-founder of Twitter, Jack Dorsey, announced the launch of a new decentralized peer-to-peer messaging app named Bitchat. The application is currently available on Apple‚Äôs beta‚Äêtesting service TestFlight. On Sunday evening, Dorsey shared Bitchat‚Äôs whitepaper along with a TestFlight link for anyone interested in trying the app. He said his weekend project was to learn about ‚Äúbluetooth mesh networks, relays and store and forward models, message encryption models, and a few other things.‚Äù Bitchat works without the internet Bitchat‚Äôs whitepaper states that the application doesn‚Äôt rely on internet infrastructure. The app uses Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) mesh networks, which provide ephemeral, encrypted communication. This setup ensures the application stays operational even during internet blackouts or censorship. When somebody sends a message to another user, the message is end-to-end encrypted and it stays in the device memory. No data is saved on a server. Also, using the app doesn‚Äôt require a phone number or an email address. This makes Bitchat more private compared to popular messaging apps like WhatsApp that rely on Meta‚Äôs data servers. Since Bitchat relies on BLE mesh networks, each device acts as both a client and a server. Nearby devices (within 30 meters) form clusters. When a device from one cluster comes into the range of a device from another cluster, they act as a bridge, linking the two groups. This allows messages to hop from cluster to cluster until they reach their intended recipient. The whitepaper further dives into the messaging app‚Äôs architecture, protocols, and safety mechanisms. Source: Jack Dorsey via X. How does Bitchat enhance privacy? Bitchat injects dummy messages at random intervals of 30‚Äì120 seconds and it adds 50‚Äì500 milliseconds delays to real transmissions. This makes it statistically impossible for anyone to distinguish genuine messages or correlate timing with user activity. Messages do not stay in the device‚Äôs memory forever. The decentralized app saves any message for 12 hours for regular peers while the time for favorite peers is indefinite. So even if somebody gains access to a device, they can‚Äôt trawl through years of old conversations. Bitchat has no metadata leaks since there‚Äôs no centralized servers or a service provider who can see your messages or who you‚Äôre talking to. Instead, each node only examines a TTL (time-to-live) counter and a message ID. Nodes do not keep any record of who sent the message, who will get it, or when it was sent‚Äîjust enough data to know when to stop forwarding. Bitchat provides uninterruptible communication channels in situations like protests or disaster areas where the internet may be down, overloaded, or actively blocked. Besides founding Twitter and building Bitchat today, Jack Dorsey co-founded and led Block (formerly Square). He backed decentralized social protocols such as Bluesky and Nostr. In recent years Dorsey drove the development of Web5 and other decentralized applications while advocating for Bitcoin adoption. headline: Bitcoin Miner CleanSpark Produced 685 BTC in June, Hit 16.15 J/TH in Efficiency

The company secured contracts for an additional 179 megawatts (MW) of power, raising its total contracted capacity to 987 MW. The new capacity is expected to support more than 10 EH/s of incremental hashrate. CleanSpark also launched its Digital Asset Management program, which includes a spot sales strategy and derivative overlay. The initiative showed initial gains in June, supporting the company‚Äôs broader focus on optimization and operating leverage.

headline: Ethereum Eyes 16.7M Gas Cap Under Vitalik Buterin‚Äôs New Proposal
summary: Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin and Ethereum Foundation researcher Toni Wahrst√§tter have proposed a ceiling on how much gas a single transaction can use, and aim to tighten security while preserving efficiency as the protocol matures. The draft proposal, EIP-7983, sets a 16.77 million gas limit per transaction. Interestingly, this is a significant change from the current architecture, where a single transaction can consume an entire block‚Äôs gas allowance. Developers argue this open-ended design exposes Ethereum to denial-of-service (DoS) risks, inconsistent network load, and slower block verification, especially as the chain supports increasingly complex DeFi and zero-knowledge applications. EIP-7983 By introducing a hard cap, Buterin and Wahrst√§tter seek to enforce more predictable resource usage without significantly disrupting typical user activity, noting that most transactions currently fall well below the proposed threshold. Transactions of more than the 16.77 million gas cap would be rejected during validation. Such a move would ensure oversized transactions cannot enter blocks, while the block gas limit itself would remain adjustable by validators under existing consensus rules. The authors frame the move as part of a broader effort to simplify Ethereum‚Äôs base layer and improve network reliability, which essentially echoes Buterin‚Äôs recent calls to streamline protocol design inspired by Bitcoin‚Äôs minimalist ethos. Easing zkVM Constraints Developers working on zkVMs and parallel execution engines have highlighted difficulties in handling transactions with unpredictable gas sizes. They believe a fixed ceiling could ease engineering constraints and allow better subdivision of workloads across threads. The cap is also expected to reduce the risk of any single transaction monopolizing block resources, thereby improving consistency in execution times and block propagation. While the proposed limit may require some large deployments to split transactions into smaller segments, it aligns with Ethereum‚Äôs longer-term goal of supporting modular and provable systems while maintaining user experience. EIP-7983 builds on the now-stagnant EIP-7825 but with a lower ceiling. The proposal is currently in draft status and is now open for community discussion as developers assess its practical impact on the network. headline: Bitcoin Slips Below $108K, Erases Weekend Gains as Trump Ramps Up Tariffs
summary: Bitcoin's BTC very modest weekend rally modestly reversed on Monday as President Trump's tariff policies took center stage again. The largest cryptocurrency slipped below $108,000 during the U.S. afternoon, down 0.8% over the past 24 hours. Changing hands at around $107,700, BTC has round-tripped all of the move to $109,700 on Sunday. Ethereum's ether ETH was 0.6% lower, while smaller cryptos including Solana's SOL SOL, dogecoin DOGE, Sui's SUI SUI declined 1%-2%. XRP XRP outperformed with more than a 2% gain. Dampening investor sentiment was the President Trump ramping up tariffs even while delaying his self-imposed July 9 trade deal deadline to August 1. In letters from the White House to counterparts in Japan and South Korea, Trump set 25% tariffs on products from those two countries starting on August 1. Trump shared more letters on Truth Social, revealing a 25% levies against Kazakhstan and Malaysia , 30% against South Africa , and 40% for Myanmar and Laos . In a Monday social post, Trump also threatened additional tariffs on countries aligning with policies by the BRICS, a loose intergovernmental group of countries including Brazil, India, China and Russia. In a press conference, White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said the government will send out letters to more countries about tariff rates or announce trade deals in the coming days. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 indexes were lower by about 1% on Monday, while yields on 10-year U.S. Treasury bonds also headed higher, nearing 4.4%. UPDATE (July 7, 18:43 UTC): Adds tariffs against Kazakhstan, Malaysia, Laos, Myanmar and South Africa.

headline: Strategy Pauses Bitcoin Buying, Focuses on New Funding Channels
summary: Nasdaq-listed firm Strategy, led by Michael Saylor, had paused its Bitcoin purchases between June 30 and July 6. As revealed in a new filing, this marks the first time the software intelligence firm has not added to its holdings since early April. Despite the pause, Strategy remains the largest corporate holder of Bitcoin. Strategy Holds Over $65B in Bitcoin As of July 6, Strategy holds 597,325 BTC, valued at over $65 billion. The average purchase price for these coins is approximately $70,982, with a total acquisition cost of around $42.4 billion. This puts the company‚Äôs unrealized profit at roughly $22.6 billion. Strategy‚Äôs Bitcoin holdings now represent about 2.8% of the total 21 million Bitcoin supply. The pause in Bitcoin purchases comes after a period of aggressive acquisitions. The Virginia-based company had bought 4,980 BTC for $531.9 million between June 23 and June 29. However, the pace has slowed in recent weeks. This comes as the firm shifted focus from selling common stock to offering perpetual preferred stock to raise capital . In late June, Strategy raised $6.8 billion through its at-the-market equity programs, which included sales of Class A common stock and various types of preferred shares. Strategy‚Äôs Long-Term Bitcoin Plan Expands, Draws Mixed Views The company‚Äôs capital raising efforts support a long-term plan called the ‚Äú42/42‚Äù program, which aims to raise $84 billion for Bitcoin acquisitions by 2027. This is double the original target under the earlier ‚Äú21/21‚Äù plan. To date, Strategy has raised billions by selling shares and convertible notes, with additional funds still available through its ongoing programs. Furthermore, the firm‚Äôs market value has reached $110 billion, which is significantly higher than the net asset value (NAV) of its Bitcoin holdings. Some analysts believe this premium is justified due to the company‚Äôs strong equity-to-Bitcoin cycle. Others, however, have raised concerns about a possible negative feedback loop from overdependence on Bitcoin valuations. A recent class action lawsuit also claims that Strategy misled investors about its Bitcoin strategy. Quarterly Results Reflect Strong Bitcoin Gains Strategy recently released its second-quarter results. It reported an unrealized gain of $14.05 billion on its BTC holdings. During the second quarter, Strategy also entered into a loan agreement allowing it to borrow up to $31.1 million for capital purchases. Meanwhile, other companies like Metaplanet are adopting similar Bitcoin strategies . Tether-backed Twenty One, Trump Media, and GameStop are among other new entrants following this trend. Following this news, Strategy‚Äôs stock closed at $403.99, up by 0.4% on July 5. As of Monday morning, the shares dropped slightly in pre-market trading but are still up by over 34% this year. In comparison, the top coin is up 16.9% since the start of the year, currently trading at $108,346. headline: Bit Digital‚Äôs Astounding Pivot: Why Ethereum Staking is the Future for This Crypto Miner
summary: BitcoinWorld Bit Digital‚Äôs Astounding Pivot: Why Ethereum Staking is the Future for This Crypto Miner In a move that‚Äôs sending ripples through the cryptocurrency world, U.S. Bitcoin miner Bit Digital (Nasdaq: BTBT) has announced a significant strategic shift. The company recently sold 280 BTC, redirecting the proceeds to acquire additional Ethereum, boosting its ETH holdings to an impressive 100,603 ETH. This isn‚Äôt just a simple asset reallocation; it signals a fundamental change in Bit Digital‚Äôs operational focus, moving away from traditional Bitcoin mining towards the burgeoning world of Ethereum staking and reserves. What does this mean for the future of crypto mining, and why are companies like Bit Digital making such bold decisions? Bit Digital‚Äôs Astounding Strategic Pivot: Why the Shift? The news from Bit Digital isn‚Äôt just about selling one asset to buy another; it‚Äôs a clear indication of a long-term strategic re-evaluation. The company had previously signaled its intention to scale back its Bitcoin mining operations, a business historically defined by intense competition, significant energy consumption, and substantial hardware investment. Their new direction, as reported by Jin10.com, points squarely towards Ethereum staking and building up their ETH reserves. But what drives such a dramatic change for a company synonymous with Bitcoin mining? Several factors likely play into this pivot: Evolving Market Dynamics: The cryptocurrency landscape is constantly shifting. With Ethereum‚Äôs transition to Proof-of-Stake (PoS) via The Merge, the entire ecosystem around ETH has changed, opening new avenues for revenue generation beyond energy-intensive mining. Operational Efficiency: Bitcoin mining is resource-heavy, requiring massive capital expenditure on ASICs (Application-Specific Integrated Circuits) and significant ongoing energy costs. Ethereum staking, on the other hand, offers a potentially more capital-efficient and environmentally friendly way to earn returns on digital assets. Revenue Stability: While mining rewards are subject to network difficulty and Bitcoin‚Äôs price volatility, staking can offer more predictable yields, providing a steadier income stream for companies looking to de-risk their operations. Future Growth Potential: Bit Digital may see greater long-term growth and stability in the Ethereum ecosystem, especially as its utility expands with various decentralized applications (dApps), NFTs, and DeFi protocols. From Pickaxe to Protocol: The Evolution of Bitcoin Mining For years, Bitcoin mining has been the bedrock of the crypto industry, a process essential for securing the network and validating transactions. Miners use powerful computers to solve complex cryptographic puzzles, and the first one to solve the puzzle gets to add a new block to the blockchain and earn newly minted Bitcoin. This Proof-of-Work (PoW) consensus mechanism has been incredibly robust, but it comes with its own set of challenges: Energy Consumption: PoW mining is notoriously energy-intensive, drawing criticism for its environmental impact. This has led to increasing regulatory scrutiny and public pressure. Hardware Dependency: Miners must constantly invest in the latest, most powerful mining rigs, which can be expensive and quickly become obsolete. Centralization Concerns: The sheer cost of entry can lead to mining operations becoming concentrated in the hands of a few large entities or pools, raising decentralization concerns. Price Volatility: The profitability of Bitcoin mining is directly tied to the price of BTC. Sharp market downturns can quickly turn profitable operations into loss-making ones. Bit Digital‚Äôs decision highlights a growing trend among some miners to explore alternatives or diversify their operations beyond pure PoW mining. This isn‚Äôt to say Bitcoin mining is dead, but rather that the industry is maturing, and companies are seeking more sustainable and diversified revenue models. Embracing the Future: The Promise of Ethereum Staking In stark contrast to Bitcoin‚Äôs Proof-of-Work, Ethereum has fully transitioned to Proof-of-Stake, a mechanism where participants (validators) ‚Äòstake‚Äô their ETH as collateral to validate transactions and secure the network. In return, they earn rewards. This is where Ethereum staking comes into play as a compelling alternative for companies like Bit Digital. Here‚Äôs why staking is gaining traction: Energy Efficiency: Staking consumes significantly less energy than mining, making it a more environmentally friendly option and aligning with growing ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) investment trends. Passive Income: Stakers earn a yield on their locked ETH, providing a relatively stable and predictable source of income, unlike the more variable nature of mining rewards. Reduced Hardware Costs: Staking requires minimal hardware compared to mining, significantly reducing capital expenditure and ongoing maintenance costs. Network Security: Stakers are incentivized to act honestly, as malicious behavior can lead to their staked ETH being ‚Äòslashed‚Äô (penalized). Let‚Äôs look at a simplified comparison: Feature Bitcoin Mining (PoW) Ethereum Staking (PoS) Consensus Mechanism Proof-of-Work (PoW) Proof-of-Stake (PoS) Resource Requirement High energy, specialized hardware (ASICs) ETH capital, minimal hardware Environmental Impact High Low Revenue Source Block rewards (new BTC), transaction fees Staking rewards (ETH) Entry Barrier High (capital for hardware, energy access) Lower (32 ETH for solo, less for pools) Diversifying the Crypto Portfolio: What This Means for Bit Digital By selling a substantial portion of its Bitcoin and investing heavily in Ethereum, Bit Digital is fundamentally reshaping its crypto portfolio . This move isn‚Äôt just about switching one digital asset for another; it‚Äôs about altering the core business model from a capital-intensive, hardware-dependent operation to one focused on yield generation through asset management and validation services. For Bit Digital, this could mean: Improved Financial Metrics: Potentially higher profit margins due to lower operational costs, and more predictable revenue streams from staking rewards. Enhanced Risk Management: Diversifying away from a sole reliance on Bitcoin‚Äôs price and mining difficulty could cushion the company against market downturns specific to PoW mining. Strategic Positioning: Bit Digital positions itself as an early mover in the institutional Ethereum staking space, potentially attracting new investors interested in sustainable crypto operations. Asset Growth: With 100,603 ETH, Bit Digital has a significant base from which to generate substantial staking rewards, further growing its Ethereum holdings. This shift reflects a mature understanding of the evolving digital asset landscape and a proactive approach to adapting business strategies to new opportunities. Broader Implications for Digital Assets: A Shifting Landscape? Bit Digital‚Äôs pivot is not an isolated incident; it‚Äôs a strong signal within the broader world of digital assets . As the crypto industry matures, companies are increasingly looking for sustainable and diversified revenue models. Ethereum‚Äôs successful transition to Proof-of-Stake has opened up a new frontier for institutional participation, moving beyond just holding assets to actively participating in network security and earning yields. This trend could lead to several significant implications: Increased Institutional Staking: More traditional mining companies or even new players might follow Bit Digital‚Äôs lead, boosting the amount of ETH staked and further securing the Ethereum network. Environmental Focus: The emphasis on energy efficiency in PoS could put more pressure on PoW networks like Bitcoin to address their environmental footprint, potentially accelerating innovation in green mining solutions. Evolution of Crypto Business Models: We might see a proliferation of hybrid models, where companies engage in both traditional mining and staking, or even fully transition to staking-as-a-service providers. Investor Sentiment: This strategic shift could influence how investors view crypto companies, favoring those with more diversified, sustainable, and yield-generating operations. While Bitcoin mining remains a vital component of the crypto ecosystem, the rise of Ethereum staking presents a compelling alternative that many are beginning to explore seriously. Bit Digital is simply at the forefront of this potential paradigm shift. Challenges and Considerations for the Transition While the move to Ethereum staking offers numerous benefits, it‚Äôs not without its challenges. Bit Digital will need to navigate complexities such as: Smart Contract Risks: Staking often involves interacting with smart contracts, which, despite rigorous auditing, can carry inherent risks of bugs or vulnerabilities. Slashing Penalties: Validators on the Ethereum network can face penalties (slashing) if they behave maliciously or fail to meet their duties (e.g., prolonged downtime). This requires robust infrastructure and monitoring. Liquidity Management: Staked ETH is locked and may not be immediately accessible, requiring careful liquidity planning, although liquid staking solutions are emerging to mitigate this. Regulatory Landscape: The regulatory environment for staking services is still evolving, and companies must stay compliant with new rules. However, the potential rewards of a more stable, less capital-intensive, and environmentally friendlier revenue stream seem to outweigh these challenges for Bit Digital. Actionable Insights for Investors and Other Miners What can we learn from Bit Digital‚Äôs bold move? For Investors: Pay attention to how crypto companies are diversifying their revenue streams. Those embracing new, sustainable models like staking might offer more stable long-term growth. Evaluate a company‚Äôs entire crypto portfolio, not just its primary mining activity. For Other Miners: This is a wake-up call to explore alternative revenue generation. Consider diversifying your operations, investing in staking, or exploring other yield-generating opportunities within the crypto space. The future of crypto profitability might lie beyond pure PoW. For the Crypto Market: The increasing institutional adoption of staking strengthens the underlying networks and legitimizes these new forms of participation. It‚Äôs a sign of a maturing market. Conclusion: A New Horizon for Crypto Companies Bit Digital‚Äôs strategic pivot from extensive Bitcoin mining to a focus on Ethereum staking and reserves is a landmark decision. It highlights a growing recognition within the industry that sustainable, efficient, and diversified revenue streams are crucial for long-term success in the dynamic world of digital assets. This move not only redefines Bit Digital‚Äôs business model but also sets a precedent, signaling a potential broader shift in how crypto companies approach asset management and network participation. As the crypto landscape continues to evolve, we can expect more players to explore innovative strategies that leverage the full potential of both established and emerging blockchain technologies.
